issues.description: The UML/problem statement declares the Pneumatic interface with methods raisePressure(int) and openValve(). In the solution, Pneumatic.java declares raisePressure(int) and releasePressure() (method name mismatch), while the solution classes LaunchedDropdownTower and LaunchedRollerCoaster implement a method named openValve(). This creates a signature/name mismatch between the interface and the implementing classes (and contradicts the UML). As written, the solution is internally inconsistent and would not compile: implementing classes do not implement the interface method releasePressure(), and the interface does not declare openValve() as required by the UML/problem. This will confuse students about the correct method name to use and prevents following the intended design.
issues.suggested_fix: Align the Pneumatic interface with the UML/problem statement: declare raisePressure(int) and openValve() in Pneumatic. Concretely, replace releasePressure() with openValve() in Pneumatic.java (both in the template and solution). Alternatively, if releasePressure() is the intended API, update the UML/problem text and the implementing classes to use releasePressure() consistently. Ensure interface and all implementing classes use the same method name/signature.

issues.description: The problem statement (UML) defines a Pneumatic interface with methods raisePressure(int pressureIncrease) and openValve(). In the solution repository, the Pneumatic interface declares raisePressure(int) and releasePressure() (different name). Meanwhile the solution's LaunchedDropdownTower and LaunchedRollerCoaster classes override openValve(). This creates a direct naming mismatch: the interface method in the solution is called releasePressure(), but the UML/problem and the implementing classes use openValve(). This inconsistency breaks the conceptual mapping (and would cause compilation errors) and forces students to resolve which method name is correct.
issues.suggested_fix: Rename the method in the solution Pneumatic interface from releasePressure() to openValve() so it matches the UML/problem statement and the implementing classes (and update any references). Alternatively, if releasePressure() is the intended name, update the problem statement/UML and the implementing classes to use releasePressure() consistently. Prefer aligning the solution to the UML's openValve() to avoid confusion.
